name: Present Perfect Simple
description: Use present perfect to connect past and present (experience, unfinished time, recent past)
examples: I have lived here for 5 years
Have you ever been to Japan?
She has just left

name: Present Perfect Continuous
description: Use present perfect continuous for ongoing actions with duration and recent activity
examples: I have been studying for 3 hours
She has been working here since 2020
It has been raining all day

name: Past Perfect
description: Use past perfect to show earlier past events before another past event
examples: When I arrived, she had already left
I had never seen snow before I moved to Canada

name: Past Perfect Continuous
description: Use past perfect continuous for ongoing past actions before another past event
examples: I had been waiting for an hour when she arrived
They had been living there for 10 years before they moved

name: Used to for Past Habits
description: Use 'used to' to describe past habits and states that are no longer true
examples: I used to play tennis when I was younger
She didn't use to like coffee
Did you use to live in Paris?

name: Would for Past Habits
description: Use 'would' to describe repeated past actions (not states)
examples: Every summer, we would go to the beach
He would always help me with homework

name: Defining Relative Clauses
description: Use defining relative clauses with who, which, that, where, when, whose
examples: The book that I bought is great
The woman who lives next door is a doctor
That's the place where we met

name: Non-Defining Relative Clauses
description: Use non-defining relative clauses with commas for additional information
examples: My sister, who lives in London, is a teacher
This book, which I bought yesterday, is interesting

name: First Conditional
description: Use first conditional for real future possibilities (if + present, will)
examples: If it rains, I will stay home
If you study hard, you will pass the exam

name: Second Conditional
description: Use second conditional for unreal/hypothetical present situations (if + past, would)
examples: If I had more time, I would travel
If I were you, I would study more
What would you do if you won the lottery?

name: Third Conditional
description: Use third conditional for unreal past situations (if + past perfect, would have)
examples: If I had studied, I would have passed
If she had known, she would have told you

name: Zero Conditional
description: Use zero conditional for general truths and facts (if + present, present)
examples: If you heat water to 100Â°C, it boils
If I don't sleep well, I feel tired

name: Future Perfect
description: Use future perfect to describe actions completed before a future time
examples: By next year, I will have finished my degree
She will have left before you arrive

name: Future Continuous
description: Use future continuous for actions in progress at a specific future time
examples: This time next week, I will be lying on the beach
At 8pm tonight, I will be having dinner

name: Modals of Deduction Present
description: Use modals for deduction about present situations (must, can't, might, may, could)
examples: She must be tired
He can't be at home
They might be late
It could be true

name: Modals of Deduction Past
description: Use modals for deduction about past situations (must have, can't have, might have, may have, could have)
examples: She must have left early
He can't have known
They might have forgotten
It could have been worse

name: Passive Voice Present Simple
description: Use passive voice in present simple when agent is unknown or unimportant
examples: English is spoken here
The letters are delivered every day
Rice is grown in Asia

name: Passive Voice Past Simple
description: Use passive voice in past simple
examples: The building was built in 1990
She was invited to the party
The letter was sent yesterday

name: Passive Voice Present Perfect
description: Use passive voice in present perfect
examples: The work has been finished
The problem has been solved
Have you been told the news?

name: Passive with Modals
description: Use passive voice with modal verbs
examples: The window must be cleaned
It can be done tomorrow
The report should be written by Friday

name: Reported Speech - Statements
description: Report statements using backshift of tenses
examples: She said (that) she was tired
He told me he had finished
They said they would come

name: Reported Speech - Questions
description: Report questions using if/whether or question words
examples: She asked if I was ready
He asked me where I lived
They asked when I would arrive

name: Reported Speech - Commands
description: Report commands and requests using infinitive structures
examples: She told me to wait
He asked me not to leave
They ordered us to stop

name: Wish - Present Regrets
description: Use 'wish' with past simple for present regrets
examples: I wish I had more time
I wish I were taller
She wishes she lived in Paris

name: Wish - Past Regrets
description: Use 'wish' with past perfect for past regrets
examples: I wish I had studied harder
She wishes she hadn't said that
They wish they had come

name: Causative Have/Get
description: Use causative structures to show someone else does something for you
examples: I had my hair cut
She's getting her car repaired
We need to have the house painted

name: Gerunds and Infinitives
description: Use gerunds and infinitives after specific verbs correctly
examples: I enjoy reading
She decided to go
He suggested going
I want to learn

name: Quantifiers Advanced
description: Use advanced quantifiers (a few, a little, plenty of, a great deal of, several)
examples: There are several options
I have a little money
She has plenty of time

name: Articles Advanced Usage
description: Use articles correctly in advanced contexts (zero article, generalizations)
examples: Life is beautiful (general)
The life of a student (specific)
People need water (zero article)

name: Vocabulary Set - Work and Employment
description: Learn vocabulary related to jobs, workplace, career, employment terms
examples: career, salary, promotion, colleague, manager, contract, resign, apply for, interview, skills

name: Vocabulary Set - Education
description: Learn vocabulary related to education, learning, academic life
examples: degree, course, subject, semester, lecture, assignment, grade, scholarship, graduate, undergraduate

name: Vocabulary Set - Environment
description: Learn vocabulary related to environment, nature, climate, sustainability
examples: pollution, climate change, recycle, renewable energy, deforestation, carbon footprint, sustainable, biodiversity

name: Vocabulary Set - Technology
description: Learn vocabulary related to technology, computers, internet, digital life
examples: device, download, upload, software, hardware, app, social media, browse, stream, backup

name: Vocabulary Set - Social Issues
description: Learn vocabulary related to social topics, problems, society
examples: inequality, poverty, discrimination, human rights, immigration, unemployment, crime, welfare, justice

name: Phrasal Verbs Common
description: Learn and use common phrasal verbs in everyday situations
examples: give up, take off, put on, turn on/off, look after, find out, get on with, run out of

name: Collocations Basic
description: Recognize and use basic collocations (verb+noun, adjective+noun)
examples: make a decision, do homework, strong coffee, heavy rain, catch a cold, pay attention

name: Linking Words - Contrast
description: Use linking words to show contrast (although, however, despite, in spite of, whereas)
examples: Although it was raining, we went out
However, I disagree
Despite the rain, we enjoyed it

name: Linking Words - Addition
description: Use linking words to add information (furthermore, moreover, in addition, besides)
examples: Furthermore, the price is good
In addition to this, it's convenient
Moreover, it saves time

name: Linking Words - Cause and Effect
description: Use linking words to show cause and effect (because, therefore, as a result, consequently)
examples: I was tired because I didn't sleep well
Therefore, we decided to wait
As a result, prices increased

name: Describing Trends and Changes
description: Describe trends, changes, and developments using appropriate vocabulary
examples: increase, decrease, rise, fall, grow, decline, improve, worsen, remain stable, fluctuate

name: Abstract Concepts Basic
description: Express and discuss basic abstract ideas and concepts
examples: freedom, success, happiness, progress, knowledge, experience, relationship, opportunity

name: Expressing Opinions Developed
description: Express and justify opinions on various topics with reasons
examples: In my opinion...
I think/believe that... because...
From my point of view...

name: Agreeing and Disagreeing Politely
description: Agree and disagree politely with justification
examples: I agree with you that...
I see your point, but...
I'm not sure I agree because...

name: Giving Presentations Basic
description: Give simple presentations on familiar topics with basic structure
examples: Today I'm going to talk about...
First, I'll cover... Then... Finally...

name: Participating in Discussions
description: Participate actively in discussions on familiar topics
examples: What do you think about...?
Can I add something?
That's a good point

name: Narrating Experiences Detailed
description: Narrate experiences, events, and stories with detail and sequence
examples: Let me tell you about...
It all started when...
After that... In the end...

name: Making Comparisons Developed
description: Compare and contrast ideas, options, and situations effectively
examples: Compared to...
On the one hand... On the other hand...
Similarly...
In contrast...

name: Hypothesizing and Speculating
description: Make hypotheses and speculate about possibilities
examples: I suppose...
It might be...
Perhaps...
I imagine that...

name: Writing Essays Basic
description: Write simple essays with introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion (200-250 words)
examples: Essay structure: intro with thesis, 2-3 body paragraphs with topic sentences, conclusion

name: Writing Formal Letters
description: Write formal letters with appropriate register and format
examples: Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to... I look forward to hearing from you. Yours faithfully

name: Writing Informal Letters
description: Write informal letters and emails to friends with appropriate tone
examples: Dear John, How are you? I hope you're well. Write back soon. Love, Maria

name: Writing Reviews
description: Write simple reviews of books, films, restaurants, products
examples: I recently read/watched... It was excellent/disappointing because... I would/wouldn't recommend it

name: Writing Reports Simple
description: Write simple reports presenting information clearly with sections
examples: Introduction, Findings, Conclusion, Recommendations

name: Paragraph Structure
description: Write well-structured paragraphs with topic sentence, support, and conclusion
examples: Topic sentence + supporting details + examples + concluding sentence

name: Cohesion and Coherence
description: Use cohesive devices (pronouns, linking words, reference words) for text coherence
examples: Use this, that, these, those, it, they to refer back
Use linking words to connect ideas

name: Reading - Skimming
description: Skim texts quickly to get the main idea and general understanding
examples: Read title, headings, first sentences to get general idea quickly

name: Reading - Scanning
description: Scan texts to locate specific information quickly
examples: Look for names, numbers, dates, keywords without reading everything

name: Reading - Inference Developed
description: Make developed inferences about meaning, purpose, and attitude from context
examples: What is the writer's purpose?
What does the writer imply?
What is the tone?

name: Reading - Vocabulary from Context
description: Guess meaning of unfamiliar words from context clues
examples: Use context, word parts, surrounding sentences to guess meaning

name: Listening - Attitudes and Opinions
description: Identify speakers' attitudes, opinions, and feelings from tone and language
examples: Does the speaker agree or disagree?
Is the speaker enthusiastic or critical?

name: Listening - Note-Taking Basic
description: Take simple notes while listening to talks, lectures, presentations
examples: Note key points, main ideas, important details using abbreviations

name: Listening - Extended Speech
description: Understand extended speech and follow complex lines of argument on familiar topics
examples: Follow talks, lectures, presentations of 10+ minutes

name: Pronunciation - Sentence Stress
description: Use sentence stress to emphasize important content words
examples: I LIKE coffee (not tea)
I like COFfee (not juice)

name: Pronunciation - Rhythm
description: Recognize and produce English rhythm patterns (stress-timed)
examples: DA da da DA da da (stress-timed rhythm)

name: Pronunciation - Intonation for Meaning
description: Use intonation to convey meaning and attitude
examples: Really? (surprise) vs Really. (confirmation)
Rising tone for uncertainty, falling for certainty

name: Paraphrasing
description: Paraphrase ideas using different words while keeping the same meaning
examples: It's expensive = It costs a lot
He's intelligent = He's smart/clever

name: Repair Strategies Developed
description: Use developed repair strategies (clarification, confirmation, reformulation)
examples: Do you mean...?
Let me rephrase that
What I meant to say was...

name: Discourse Markers
description: Use discourse markers to structure speech and manage conversation
examples: Well...
Actually...
By the way...
Anyway...
So...

name: Turn-Taking
description: Manage turn-taking in conversations appropriately
examples: Can I just say...?
If I could add something...
Sorry to interrupt, but...

name: Maintaining Fluency
description: Keep speaking with minimal pauses and hesitations on familiar topics
examples: Speak smoothly with natural pauses, not long gaps

name: Self-Monitoring Developed
description: Monitor and correct errors in grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation during speech
examples: I go... went there yesterday
She don't... doesn't like it
